blocks.text: This can be put in the form given on p. 120, Part I, if for (b – a) we write L, and for BE and DF their respective values r_1 and r_2.
Thus h_n = r_1 - r_2 = ρ_1 - ρ_2.
So that the volume of the zone = π (r_1^2 - r_2^2).
Length of Arc. - Consider a small portion of a curve, PQ in Fig. 49, P and Q being points near to one another.

blocks.caption: Fig. 49
blocks.description: The diagram illustrates the small length of arc PQ, the relationship between the length and coordinates, and the calculus involved in determining the change in these lengths.

blocks.text: The small length of arc PQ is denoted by ds, so that a complete arc would be denoted by ∫ ds.
Let PM = x, and QM = y.
Hence when ∆x becomes infinitely small, ds becomes ds.

We can write:  
   ds = √(dx^2 + dy^2)  
or  
    rac{dy}{dx} =  rac{8y}{8x}.
